title: R44268
content: Operation Ranch Hand was a U.S. military program during the Vietnam War that sprayed millions of gallons of herbicides, including Agent Orange, over southern Vietnam. The herbicides contained TCDD, a toxic and carcinogenic compound. Dioxin "hot spots" have been identified in Vietnam, with high contamination levels at airbases like Bien Hoa and Danang. The A Luoi Valley was a crucial part of the Ho Chi Minh Trail used by North Vietnamese forces. The A Luoi Valley, south of Quang Tri and west of Danang, was a key segment of the Ho Chi Minh Trail, heavily sprayed during the Vietnam War. The former U.S. military base in the valley is a recognized "hot spot" for Agent Orange contamination. Recent U.S. efforts to address environmental damage and health issues in Vietnam have helped improve bilateral relations. President Obama pledged continued support for cleanup efforts, including removing unexploded landmines and bombs, and assisting with dioxin cleanup at Bien Hoa Air Base. The United States will assist in the cleanup of dioxin contamination at Bien Hoa Air Base in Vietnam, following successful efforts at Danang Airport. The Trump Administration continues to provide assistance for addressing the Agent Orange/dioxin issue, as pledged by President Obama. President Trump and Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc have committed to working together on war legacy issues. The joint statement between Trump and Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc committed to addressing war legacy issues, including dioxin remediation at Da Nang and Bien Hoa Airports, and the removal of unexploded ordnances. The environmental remediation of Danang Airport was celebrated on November 10, 2017, and a Memorandum of Intent was signed for dioxin decontamination at Bien Hoa. Six contracts awarded for environmental assessment and remediation project at Danang airport, including assessment of Bien Hoa airbase. Thermal desorption of contaminated soil done in two phases, with Phase 1 starting in April 2014 and Phase 2 excavation beginning in January 2015. The excavation for Phase 2 at Danang airport began in January 2015, involving draining three small lakes and removing exposed lake beds. The treatment of 45,000 m3 of Phase 2 soil started in November 2016 and was completed in August 2017. Progress was delayed due to weather conditions during Vietnam's rainy season and the need for more soil decontamination than initially estimated. Additionally, the secondary treatment facility was shut down in July 2014 for system changes, and raising the ambient temperature of Phase 1 soil took longer than expected. USAID's Office of Inspector General conducted an internal audit in November 2014, identifying potential risks. The USAID's Office of Inspector General conducted an internal audit in November 2014, highlighting risks in the environmental remediation project at Danang Airport. The audit identified issues with inclement weather, cooling treated soil, lack of a formal risk management plan, inaccurate performance data from CDM, and inadequate training for Vietnamese officials. Recommendations were made for better risk management, training, and data documentation. The completion of the project was marked with a ceremony on November 7, 2018. The completion of the Danang Airport environmental remediation project took longer and cost more than initially projected by USAID due to underestimating contamination. 162,500 cubic meters of soil were contaminated, not 72,900 as expected. The Bien Hoa airbase, a dioxin "hot spot" where Agent Orange spraying missions occurred during the war, is being considered for a cleanup similar to Danang airport. Congressional interest in Agent Orange/dioxin in Vietnam focuses on providing assistance for environmental damage and oversight of aid utilization by the State Department and USAID. The State Department and USAID have requested funding for decontamination of dioxin "hot spots" in Vietnam, with Congress generally appropriating funds for health and disability services in affected areas. Various programs for persons with disabilities have been conducted near known Agent Orange sites using these funds. The Obama Administration budget requests did not explicitly include funding for health and disability assistance programs in areas contaminated with Agent Orange or dioxin. However, the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019 designates funds for health and disability services in these contaminated areas, with a minimum of $12,500,000 allocated for such programs. The Victims of Agent Orange Relief Act of 2019 (H.R. 326) allocates not less than $12,500,000 for health and disability programs in areas affected by Agent Orange and dioxin contamination. Assistance will be provided for individuals with severe mobility impairment or cognitive disabilities. Covered individuals, defined as Vietnamese residents affected by Agent Orange exposure, will receive medical care, nursing services, vocational training, and medical equipment. Covered individuals, defined as Vietnamese residents affected by Agent Orange exposure, will receive medical care, nursing services, vocational training, and medical equipment. Additionally, the Act requires assistance for repairing homes, supporting research on health issues, and providing aid to healthcare institutions in Vietnam. The Secretary of State is tasked with providing assistance to healthcare institutions in Vietnam for individuals affected by Agent Orange exposure and remediating high-risk areas. Priority is given to heavily sprayed areas and military bases where Agent Orange was handled. Quarterly reports on the Act's implementation must be submitted to Congress by the Secretaries of State, Health and Human Services, and Veterans Affairs.
